Last week, Erica Banks, our former office manager, dropped by the office. Check out her message below!

‚ÄúAloha, my PHA family! I have missed seeing you since I left the front office. I've been working with my sister, Jessica Tidwell, to create a non-profit in honor of my nephew, Jack Tidwell, who was stillborn in 2012. Our non-profit, Jack's FROST (Forever Remembering Our Sweet Tidwell), focuses on literacy education and sharing books we love with as many people as possible. This year our donation is coming to you! Today at PHA we donated almost 600 books that will soon be in the hands of your children. We hope you and your family enjoy them and continue to grow your love of reading! Best of luck with your new school year, Voyagers!‚Äù - Erica Barfuss Banks

We are so blessed to be surrounded by so many great people, who create programs that benefit all children! We want to give a BIG MAHALO to the Jack FROST foundation! Thank you for thinking of our children! We love you guys! Go VOYAGERS!

Utah Pacific Island Heritage Month

Mahalo for allowing us to be a part of this program!

post_text: Day 3: 6th Grade Travel Learning. It‚Äôs all about the bones. Today we drove to Fossil Butte in Wyoming and learned about fossilization. Fossilization has 3 main steps, 1. Something dies, 2. Remains are buried in mud, 3. Time and weight turn mud to rock and turn remains to fossils. We watched as as a specialist carefully revealed a fossil with his tools. Our students were able to learn about the fossil names through etchings and saw fossils of bats, small horse, snails, fish and birds. Before leaving we shared our culture with the staff through our school Haka.

post_text: Day Two of 6th Grade Travel Learning: OREGON or BUST!! On the trail again or should we say the Oregan Trail. We traveled to Idaho just to step back in time to experience the Oregon pioneer trail. We rode the covered wagon across the plains, received our assignments to collect buffalo chips, heard stories of trail life and even had a special rockin chair brought on the trip for Kumu Mel to celebrate her birthday in. Let‚Äôs not forget the snow, the cold, mud and a stop to Hooper Springs Park for some soda tasting. We ended up with chicken and rice dinner and our nearby baby bird watching for entertainment. Because our students represented Pacific heritage so well the museum offered us a room to eat so we didn‚Äôt need to have lunch in the wet and cold not to mention a nearby school allowed us to bring our wet, soggy, cold selfies to camp out overnight so we didn‚Äôt have to sleep outside. We couldn‚Äôt be more proud of these dedicated, hard working students. Looking Forward we honor our past to better see our future.
